title: Survivors of Storm That Sank Boats and Killed 8 on Lake Say the Morning Was Quiet. Then It Was Like a Hurricane Hit
description: Survivors of the storm that caused the deaths of eight people on Lake Tahoe in June are opening up about the storm that sank several boats and led to eight deaths at a popular tourist destination.
content:
Survivors of the storm that caused the deaths of eight people on Lake Tahoe in June are opening up about the weather event that sank several boats and led to eight deaths at a popular tourist destination.

The storm moved quickly on Saturday, June 21, catching many on and around Lake Tahoe by surprise. It was quiet that morning, but eight people died after a 27-foot gold Chris-Craft boat capsized “due to a large swell, the U.S. Coast Guard previously said. Two people on that vessel survived, as did others nearby.

Speaking with , Kristofer Kierce, who owns a boat salvage company in the area, was stunned by the wreckage he saw, which included other sunken boats.

“We were in awe,” Kierce told the newspaper. “It was like a hurricane had come through.”

A bachelorette party was among those caught in the dangerous storm. Judith Saldivar, 30, was on a pontoon boat in Emerald Bay with five friends when the storm whipped through.

“In minutes, it turned from still water to ocean-like conditions,” she recalled.

The day started off calm weather-wise. Retired TV meteorologist Mark Finan said it wasn't until Saturday morning that computer models even began detecting signs that thunderstorms and snow could impact the area, according to the Times .

But eventually, the storms rolled through and temperatures plummeted. The National Weather Service previously said wind gusts were clocked at 35 to 45 mph while temperatures plummeted 15 to 25 degrees below normal.

The Coast Guard said that at the time the 27-foot boat — called "Over the Moon," according to the Times — capsized, the wind was blowing at about 30 knot winds and swells were 6 to 8 feet high.

The only people who survived the sinking were wearing life jackets, the newspaper reported.

The eight victims include DoorDash executive Joshua Antony Pickles, 37, his parents Terry Pickles, 73, and Paula Bozinovich, 71, his uncle Peter Bayes, 72, and their friends Timothy O’Leary, 71, Theresa Giullari, 66, James Guck, 69, and Stephen Lindsay, 63, according to a statement from Joshua’s wife, previously obtained by PEOPLE.

“No words can express the pain and anguish we feel knowing their lives were lost during what was meant to be a joyful time on the lake," Jordan Sugar-Carlsgaard said in a statement shared through a family spokesperson. "Our hearts go out to those who tragically lost their lives and the two survivors of this unexpected and deadly storm on Lake Tahoe."
summary: The storm that killed eight people on Lake Tahoe in June was described as "like a hurricane," according to survivors. The storm, which moved quickly, sank several boats and led to eight deaths at the popular tourist destination. The deaths occurred after a 27-foot gold Chris-Craft boat capsized due to a large swell. Two people on the other vessel survived. The only survivors were wearing life jackets. The victims included DoorDash executive Joshua Antony Pickles, his parents Terry Pickles and Paula Bozinovich, his uncle Peter Bayes, and friends Timothy O’Leary, 71, Theresa Giullari, 66, James Guck, 69, and Stephen Lindsay, 63.
shortSummary: A storm on Lake Tahoe killed eight people, including a bachelorette party, with rapid winds and massive waves, causing extensive damage and disruption.

scraped_sources.text: Cargo Ship Sinks Along with 3,000 Vehicles Likely Worth Millions After Catching Fire Weeks Earlier The 'Morning Midas' previously caught fire on June 3, authorities said By David Chiu David Chiu David Chiu is a staff writer, Human Interest, for PEOPLE. A former PEOPLE intern from 2007 to 2008, he has been writing about news and entertainment for over 10 years. People Editorial Guidelines Published on June 25, 2025 12:25PM EDT Leave a Comment A Coast Guard C-130J Super Hercules aircrew from Air Station Kodiak conducts an overflight of a fire aboard the cargo vessel Morning Midas approximately 300 miles south of Adak, Alaska, June 3, 2025. Credit : U.S. Coast Guard photo courtesy of Air Station Kodiak NEED TO KNOW The cargo ship Morning Midas was carrying about 3,000 vehicles when it caught fire on June 3All of its 22 crew members evacuated, and there were no reported injuriesThe ship later capsized and sank on June 23 Officials said that a cargo ship carrying 3,000 vehicles sank off Alaska after a fire broke out on the vessel earlier this month. The U.S. Coast Guard said in a news release that the ship Morning Midas capsized and sank in international waters approximately 450 miles southwest of Adak on Monday, June 23—adding that the vessel sank to a depth of approximately 16,400 feet. The ship was delivering new vehicles to Mexico at the time of the incident, CBS News and the Associated Press reported. The sinking comes weeks after the Coast Guard received a distress alert on June 3 that a fire occurred onboard the Morning Midas. Emergency crews and three Good Samaritan vessels responded to the scene, the Coast Guard said. All 22 crew members of the Morning Midas evacuated from the ship onto a life boat and were subsequently rescued by the crew of Cosco Hellas, one of the Good Samaritan vessels, the Coast Guard added. There were no reported injuries. A Coast Guard C-130J Super Hercules aircrew from Air Station Kodiak conducts an overflight of a fire aboard the cargo vessel Morning Midas approximately 300 miles south of Adak, Alaska, June 3, 2025. U.S. Coast Guard photo courtesy of Air Station Kodiak The maritime law enforcement agency stated that the Morning Midas was carrying a total of 3,048 vehicles, including 70 fully electric vehicles and 681 hybrid vehicles. The exact cost of the cars isn't clear, but it's expected to be worth millions of dollars. At this time, the cause of the fire is unknown. “As the search and rescue portion of our response concludes, our crews are working closely with the vessel’s manager, Zodiac Maritime, to determine the disposition of the vessel,” Rear Admiral Megan Dean of the Coast Guard’s Seventeenth District said at the time. “We are grateful for the selfless actions of the three nearby vessels who assisted in the response and the crew of motor vessel Cosco Hellas, who helped save 22 lives.” The Coast Guard said in its latest release that there were no reports of visible signs of pollution at the present moment. The agency described the Morning Midas as a 600-foot Liberian-flagged cargo vessel managed by the London-based Zodiac Maritime. The ship reportedly carried 350 metric tons of marine gas oil (MGO) and 1,530 metric tons of very low sulfur fuel oil (VLSFO). Related Stories Cargo Ship Carrying Porsches, Lamborghinis and More Luxury Cars Sinks in Atlantic Ocean After Fire U.S. Coast Guard Rescues 12 People from Stranded Cargo Ship After It Hits Rocks in Heavy Seas In a statement to PEOPLE on Wednesday, June 25, Zodiac Maritime confirmed the ship’s sinking in the North Pacific, which the company said was caused by the fire’s damage and further exacerbated by heavy weather and water ingress. "As a precaution, two salvage tugs containing pollution control equipment remain on site to monitor for any signs of pollution or debris,” Zodiac Maritime's statement read. “Their crews are safe. A specialised pollution response vessel is also en-route to the location as an additional precaution.” “All operations continue to prioritise the safety of personnel and the protection of the marine environment,” the company continued. Both the Coast Guard and Zodiac Maritime said that they remain in close contact with each other following the incident. “The safety of the responders remains our top priority,” Capt. Christopher Culpepper, the commander of Coast Guard Sector Western Alaska and U.S. Arctic, said. “We're working closely with Zodiac Maritime in an advisory capacity to ensure a swift and effective response to any potential signs of pollution.” Zodiac Maritime did not respond to PEOPLE’s question about the total value of the vehicles that were onboard the Morning Midas. How a Beautiful Summer Day on Lake Tahoe Suddenly Turned Deadly
It was a gorgeous June Saturday on Lake Tahoe, but the day turned stormy in minutes when a torrent of winds whipped up choppy waters that terrified boaters. Eight people died.
The Times looked at videos, radar and satellite imagery, and interviewed over 30 people, including meteorologists, local officials and boaters who were on the lake that day. The investigation revealed a rare set of circumstances that led to the unexpectedly dangerous day.
A calm start
A chill was in the air. Winds had pelted the Tahoe Basin the day before, prompting a wind advisory. But on the morning of June 21, puffy clouds floated across a blue sky.
Tucked in the mountains on the California-Nevada border, Lake Tahoe is popular with boaters, swimmers, hikers and skiers. Weekends are busy, and this was the first of the summer.
By late Saturday morning, the strong winds from the day before had calmed. A light breeze from the south blew over the lake.
There were no advisories from the National Weather Service that morning. The forecast warned of a slight chance for showers and thunderstorms.
It appeared to be a great day for boating.
Dani and Dan Johnston, 54 and 62, brought their son, Connor, and some of his friends in their boat to celebrate a college graduation. First stop: Gar Woods Grill & Pier, on the north shore.
Joshua Pickles, 37, a Door Dash executive, and his parents hosted guests on their 28-foot-long Chris-Craft boat, Over the Moon. They were celebrating his mother’s birthday.
Judith Saldivar, 30, and five friends on a bachelorette weekend, boarded a pontoon boat. Ms. Saldivar said the weather was gorgeous, but chilly, so she and her friends bought matching layers.
A storm forms out of sight
Around noon, thunderstorms and showers started to develop about 20 miles northwest and began moving toward the lake.
Snow fell over Donner Pass and throughout the region. Car crashes occurred on Interstate 80 and traffic backed up on highways around the lake.
On the trails surrounding a Tahoe ski resort, a 46-kilometer endurance race was cancelled when lightning got close. Hundreds of runners were brought to shelters.
“I’ve lived here for 21 years, and you see that kind of aggressive weather in the winter. It’s pretty rare to see it in the summer,” said Brendan Madigan, a race organizer.
Mr. Madigan said the forecast for the day “did not allude to what actually happened, not even in the least.”
Even in the best conditions, meteorologists cannot predict exactly when and where a thunderstorm will develop. The Tahoe Basin’s peaks and valleys add more challenges, and the June 21 storm was unusual in several ways.
Storms there commonly form in the afternoon when the sun heats the ground, causing warm air to rise and volatile clouds to form, and they usually die off quickly.
That day, a different mechanism, likely a cold air mass moving in, generated the storms.
Andrew Schwartz, with the University of California, Berkeley’s Central Sierra Snow Lab, said one of the storms sat over the mountains and grew for several hours while also sagging slowly toward the lake.
Forecasters’ computer models failed to pick up the extreme conditions.
It wasn’t until Saturday morning that some models started to show the potential for showers, thunderstorms and cold enough conditions for snow, said Mark Finan, a retired TV meteorologist who provided forecasting for the area for over 30 years. “Even what we saw in the models on Saturday morning did not exactly match up with what happened,” Mr. Finan said.
The lake was calm. With 10 people on board, Over the Moon dropped anchor in Emerald Bay, according to a report from the National Transportation Safety Board. The sheltered cove is known as one the world’s most photographed places.
Mr. Pickles was an experienced sailor, but it was only his third time operating this boat, said Sam Singer, a family representative.
Ms. Saldivar and her group also motored to Emerald Bay.
The Johnstons’ group soaked up the sunshine while traveling for lunch to Round Hill Pines, a resort on the east shore.
“You could see the rain clouds to the north, but they didn’t seem close,” Dan Johnston said. “They didn’t seem like they were moving. The normal thunderstorms usually hang there and don’t come over the lake.”
Stephen Henderson, who has worked as a boat captain for 22 summers on the lake, saw the same dark clouds rising to the north as he motored around the south shore with a tour group.
He had checked the radar before going on the water and thought the storm would be smaller and move to the east.
Winds rush over the lake
Many people reported that the weather on the lake changed around 2:15 p.m.
It was as if a faucet was suddenly turned on, and it was shooting out winds that spread across the lake’s surface.
Winds from the north traveled across the full length of the lake, creating a huge area for the waves to develop energy and grow in size.
Data from a buoy showed a change in wind direction and dramatic increase in wind speed by 3 p.m. The air temperature dipped below 40 degrees by 4 p.m.
“My crews were reporting over eight-foot swells,” said Kyle Floyd, officer in charge at the Coast Guard station in Tahoe.
Waves spilled over the bow of the Johnstons’ boat. The engine stopped.
They contacted 911 at 2:20 p.m.
“Boat sinking!”
The Johnstons were being towed by a police rescue boat when all 10 people fell into the water. Everyone was wearing a life jacket. Some people were scooped up into rescue boats and others, like Ms. Johnston, swam to shore.
“I had on a sweater and puffer jacket and jeans,” said Ms. Johnston, a former competitive swimmer. “I think we swam 250 yards to the shore.”
Large waves also spilled over into the boat where the bachelorette party huddled together.
“In minutes, it turned from still water to ocean-like conditions,” Ms. Saldivar said.
Terrified, she texted her sisters.
Mr. Henderson said the waves came one right after the other.
“Waves were coming from every direction,” he said. “There was a lot of wheel work and throttle, a lot of turning the wheel back and forth with each wave that came in.”
The Over the Moon had left Emerald Bay, and back on the open lake it faced strong winds, marble-sized hail and waves of eight to 10 feet, with water breaking over the sides and bow of the boat. The bilge pumps, which remove water from a boat’s hull, were turned on.
This area of the lake is steep, and with winds from the north pushing the waves toward the south shore, a sloshing motion may have developed in the water that “would have been very difficult for boating,” Mr. Finan said. Just before 3 p.m., hikers saw the Over the Moon capsize and called 911. Rescue teams responded.
It was too late. Six bodies were recovered that day and two more were found on Sunday. Authorities identified the victims as Joshua Pickles; his parents, Paula Bozinovich, 71, and Terry Pickles, 73; and his uncle, Peter Bayes, 72. Four of their friends also died: Timothy O’Leary, 71; Stephen Lindsay, 63; Theresa Giullari, 66; and James Guck, 69.
Two people on the boat survived — the only two who put on life jackets.
“No words can express the pain and anguish we feel,” Jordan Sugar-Carlsgaard, Joshua Pickles’s wife, said in a statement.
The next day, damaged boats were piled up at beaches on the south shore.
“We were in awe,” said Kristofer Kierce, who owns a boat salvage company. “It was like a hurricane had come through.”
Locals said they had never seen stormy conditions unfold so suddenly.
Many meteorologists The Times interviewed said a main cause on June 21 was the decaying thunderstorm just north of the lake. It may have generated a downdraft, a column of sinking cold air and precipitation that drops down from the storm cloud toward the ground.
As rain fell into dry air, some of it evaporated. This process cools the surrounding air, whipping up winds.
What we know for sure is that the technology meteorologists use to predict weather failed to pick up the localized conditions that sent winds flying across the lake.
“There was no signal on radar that would indicate a severe wind event was about to occur,” said Dawn Johnson, a meteorologist with the Weather Service in Reno.
“People underestimate Lake Tahoe. It’s a big body of water,” said Neil Lareau, an atmospheric scientist with University of Nevada, Reno. “When you’re in that summer mode, thinking about this beautiful place, thinking about this carefree summer environment, and then having a storm system more akin to what you would find in April, it can quickly become dangerous.”

Death Toll Climbs to 8 After Boat Capsizes on Lake Tahoe amid Strong Winds and Large Waves The El Dorado County Sheriff's Office said search and recovery efforts have concluded By Abigail Adams Abigail Adams Abigail Adams is a Human Interest Writer and Reporter for PEOPLE. She has been working in journalism for seven years. People Editorial Guidelines Published on June 24, 2025 10:58AM EDT 1 Comment Two more bodies have been recovered after a boat capsized on Lake Tahoe on Saturday, June 21. Credit : United States Coast Guard NEED TO KNOW Two more bodies have been recovered following the Lake Tahoe boating accident, bringing the death toll to eight, according to local authoritiesTwo people survived the crash on Saturday, June 21, they addedBad weather is believed to have contributed to the conditions on the water that led to the accident The death toll from the Lake Tahoe boating accident has climbed to eight after two more bodies were recovered from the water. The remains of the two missing people were recovered on Sunday, June 22 and Monday, June 23, according to news releases from the El Dorado County Sheriff's Office (EDCSO). Eight victims have now been recovered after the U.S. Coast Guard said a 27-foot gold Chris-Craft boat “reportedly capsized due to a large swell” on Saturday, June 21. Two people survived the crash. The EDCSO said search and recovery efforts have concluded, and that “there are no more unaccounted persons from this tragic event.” The identities of the victims will be released after “proper notifications have been made.” The scene where a boat capsized on Lake Tahoe. United States Coast Guard The EDCSO thanked numerous agencies, including members of law enforcement, fire agencies, the California State Parks and the Coast Guard, “for their assistance in this search and recovery” mission. “The Sheriff's Office expresses its deepest condolences to the families of those who have been affected by this tragic event,” authorities said. The National Weather Service (NWS) said the abnormal conditions were created after a storm that popped up in the area of the fatal incident on Saturday, June 21, according to NBC affiliate KRNV. NWS meteorologist Matthew Chyba said the winds were produced as a result of the storm “collapsing.” He added, "The storm just tracked from the north to the south and caused these waves to increase in their height.” Lake Tahoe, where a boat capsized on Saturday, June 21. Nearly 3 Dozen People Dead, Including Multiple Children, After Boat Capsizes Due to Stormy Weather The ship had been carrying around 48 passengers and five crew members at the time of the incident By Kimberlee Speakman Kimberlee Speakman Kimberlee Speakman is a digital writer at PEOPLE. She has been working at PEOPLE since 2022. She has also worked in broadcast television as a reporter for Hawaii-based news station KHON2 News. People Editorial Guidelines Published on July 19, 2025 01:27PM EDT 2 Comments A photo of Ha Long Bay in Vietnam. Credit : AP Photo/Huy Han NEED TO KNOW Multiple people, including eight children, are dead after a boat capsized The incident took place in Vietnam's Halong Bay on Saturday, July 19The ship had been carrying around 48 passengers and five crew members at the time of the accident Nearly three dozen people are dead after a boat capsized, according to multiple reports. At least 34 people, including eight children, died after the ship overturned in Vietnam's Halong Bay amid stormy weather at around 2 p.m. local time on Saturday, July 19, VNExpress, the Associated Press and Reuters reported. The boat, named the Wonder Sea, had been carrying around 48 passengers and five crew members. A majority of the travelers on the boat — including the estimated 20 children on board — were from Vietnam’s capitol Hanoi, per VNExpress and the AP. So far, 11 people have been rescued after they were found near the scene of the incident, while others remain missing, according to the outlets. A photo of rock formations in the water in Ha Long Bay. Shawn Goldberg/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty One of the individuals rescued was a 10-year-old boy, who was unconscious and admitted to a nearby hospital with several injuries, per VNExpress. A 14-year-old boy was also rescued by first responders after getting trapped in the overturned hull of the boat, VNExpress and the AP reported. "Although the ship had overturned and the cabin doors were locked, there was still an air pocket ... enough for oxygen to get in, so the boy survived," Bui Cong Hoan, the deputy head of the Ha Long Cruise Ship Association, told VNExpress. The boat capsized due to heavy winds, the local Vietnam outlet reported. Lightning and heavy rain was also reported in the area, per Reuters and the AP. Rescue divers searched several areas of the boat, including the cabin and other surrounding areas, the outlet said, but their efforts were made difficult by the weather. Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh later issued an "urgent dispatch," according to the Vietnam News Agency. The politician "extended his heartfelt sympathies to those affected and expressed deep condolences to the families of those who lost their lives." argos_summary: A sudden June 21 storm in Lake Tahoe produced winds up to 45 mph and waves 8–10 ft, capsizing a 27‑ft Chris‑Craft boat and killing eight people. The storm formed from a cold air mass moving in, with forecasters failing to predict the rapid change. Survivors wore life jackets, and the incident highlighted gaps in local weather warning systems.
